Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: "Error Estimation, Data Assimilation and Uncertainty Quantification for Multiphysics and Multiscale Processes in Geological Media"
Award.AbstractNarration:
The application of high performance computing to model subsurface processes occurring over multiple spatial and temporal scales is a science grand challenge that has important implications to society at large. Research on this grand challenge is at the confluence of advanced mathematics, computer science, fluid and solid mechanics and applied probability and statistics. The researchers propose a fresh new perspective by investigating and formulating rigorous error estimators for the numerical schemes employed to model multiphysics, multiscale processes in subsurface media. These error estimators when coupled with advanced computational methods can significantly speed up the task of uncertainty assessment and feedback control of subsurface processes. The uncertainty quantification scheme will use a computer framework that rigorously takes into account the dynamic and complex communication and coordination patterns resulting from multiphysics, multinumerics, multiscale and multidomain couplings. In addition, this project investigates realistic physical models such as carbon sequestration in saline aquifers with real field data from the Cranfield Mississippi demonstration site.

The ultimate transformative goal is to achieve predictive and decisional simulations, in which engineers reliably predict, control, and manage human interaction with geosystems. There are numerous applications that would benefit from a better understanding and integration of porous flow and solid deformation such as surface subsidence, pore collapse, cavity generation, hydraulic fracturing, thermal fracturing, wellbore collapse, sand production and fault reactivation. Moreover, the underlying computational technology will be available to other areas of science and engineering for many other applications. Included are the solver technology, and the algorithms to be developed involving high fidelity numerical simulation of partial differential equations. In order to foster collaboration between researchers with diverse backgrounds and technical expertise, the researchers propose a unique summer research residency program. Under this program the entire team will come together for a two week period during the summer and participate in a series of short courses and seminars presented by the senior researchers on the project. Outreach to high schools is planned through the sequestration training, outreach, research & education (STORE) initiative jointly between the Bureau of Economic Geology, UT Institute of Geophysics and the Center for Petroleum and Geosystems Engineering at UT Austin.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computational simulation is critical to design subsurface processes for successful environmental and energy applications. The major goal of this project was to address key mathematical and computer science challenges that are essential for effective subsurface modeling. Specific objectives included: (1) providing a comprehensive framework for a posteriori error control and adaptivity for multiphase flow computations in porous media; (2) developing multirate iterative coupling algorithms for iteratively coupled flow and geomechanics problems for both poroelastic and fractured reservoirs and improving the solution strategies for efficiently solving these problems; (3) developing an efficient method for integration of production and seismic data into reservoir models with complex connectivity using an iterative ensemble smoother; (4) integrating mesh generation, forward modeling, ensemble Kalman Filter and parameterization in an automatic workflow; (5) developing a workflow for subsurface models selection using a fast proxy that  approximates flow and geomechanics during a CO2 injection in carbon sequestration sites; (6) calibrating the fractures distribution using an advanced evolutionary multi-objective optimization method; (7) developing on-node memory sharing feature with a framework to improve data IO performance for tightly coupled in-situ workflows.

There are many research accomplishments under these goals. Here are some of the outcomes of the project.

We developed a comprehensive framework for a posteriori error control and adaptivity for multiphase flows in porous media. The framework is general and can be adapted to any numerical method. A decomposition of the error into spatial, temporal, linear and algebraic components has been obtained which allows for an insight into the critical component of error leading to the loss of accuracy. A multirate formulation for the iteratively coupled flow and geomechanics problems was introduced which exploits the inherent differences in time scales between the two processes. It allows for a much larger geomechanics time-step as compared to flow time-step thereby reducing the overall computational cost. A robust and efficient framework for simulation and integration of geomechanical responses into reservoir models was developed. We have applied this algorithm to a real-world CO2 capture and storage (CCS) project in In Salah in Algeria. Surface deformation data associated with the gas injection and production observed using interferometric synthetic­aperture radar (InSAR) was integrated to model and simulate the coupled reservoir­geomechanical responses. We introduced a new algorithm for history matching of fluvial and channelized reservoir based on combining multidimensional scaling with the ensemble smoother method. An automatic workflow that integrates generation of realizations with parameterization, Ensemble Kalman Filter, mesh generation and forward modeling was designed thus providing an effective solution to address the challenges of history matching for highly non-Gaussian fractured reservoirs. We successfully tested it on 30,000 different fracture realizations. We applied the history matching algorithm on a physically meaningful 50 fractures set generated from microseismic field. We obtained a good estimation of fracture distributions and predictions of production data improved. This increases our confidence in the predictive nature of these models, as they can be applied to physical systems not explicitly incorporated in the history matching process. We extended a model-selection framework with a fast proxy for unbiased uncertainty quantification at geologic CO2 sequestration sites. Global- and multi-objective optimization algorithms were adapted as inverse methods. The robustness of the method was verified with application to the CCS project at a fractured gas reservoir at In Salah, Central Algeria. A scalable in-memory coupling framework that can effectively utilize SSD-based deep memory hierarchy for data staging for data intensive scientific workflows was developed.

Highly sophisticated software products has been developed and benchmarked (IPARS, DataSpaces), thus providing necessary tools to address the key mathematical and computer science challenges critical for effective subsurface modeling.

In addition, this project provided training to several postdocs and graduate students. The work resulted in a plethora of publications: a book chapter, more than 40 referenced journal and conference papers, and numerous presentations. Keynotes and invited talks were given at many esteemed forums such as the SIAM Conference on Mathematical & Computational Issues in the Geosciences, SPE Reservoir Simulation Symposium, IEEE International Parallel & Distributed Processing Symposium, in many countries throughout the world.

Some of the research findings were also disseminated to the general public via the educational outreach program at UT Austin focused on communicating research related to CO2 sequestration to high school teachers, advanced high school students, and other stake holders.

The algorithms developed in this research project can be used by the environmental and petroleum industries as tools for designing efficient strategies for remediation of environmental hazards and resource recovery at highly reduced cost. The numerical methods introduced and studied here allow for reliable uncertainty and parameter estimation, which are critical for decision making. This project is a step towards the ultimate transformative goal of achieving predictive and decisional simulations, in which engineers reliably predict, control, and manage human interaction with geosystems.
